etymologies: late Middle English (denoting a deputy or delegate): from Latin substitutus ‘put in place of’, past participle of substituere, based on statuere ‘set up’

notes.text: Traditionally, the verb substitute is followed by for and means ‘put (someone or something) in place of another,’ as in she substituted the fake vase for the real one. From the late 17th century, substitute has also been used to mean ‘replace (someone or something) with someone or something else,’ as in she substituted the real vase with the fake one. This can be confusing, since the two sentences shown above mean the same thing, yet the object of the verb and the object of the preposition have swapped positions. Despite the potential confusion, the second, newer use is well established, especially in some scientific contexts and in sports (the top scorer was substituted with almost half an hour still to play), and is now generally regarded as part of standard English

definitions: a person or thing acting or serving in place of another

examples.text: soy milk is used as a substitute for dairy milk

shortDefinitions: person or thing acting or serving in place of another

definitions: a sports player nominated as eligible to replace another after a game has begun.
shortDefinitions: sports player nominated as eligible to replace another after game has begun

definitions: a person or thing that becomes the object of love or other emotion deprived of its natural outlet
shortDefinitions: person or thing that becomes object of love
